prior_works.title: Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference (2nd ed.)
prior_works.role: Foundational SCM and counterfactual semantics (abduction–action–prediction) and the formal notion of counterfactual identification.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This paper’s move from point identification of counterfactuals to partial identification with principled bounds is built on Pearl’s SCM semantics and the abduction–action–prediction framework that defines what counterfactuals are.

prior_works.title: Counterfactuals and Policy Analysis in Structural Models
prior_works.role: Introduced bounding/LP approaches for counterfactual queries in structural models, demonstrating when only bounds (often vacuous) are obtainable.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The authors extend the Balke–Pearl tradition of bounding counterfactuals by showing vacuity can persist in continuous, smooth SCMs and by proposing curvature-based assumptions to tighten these bounds.

prior_works.title: Partial Identification of Probability Distributions
prior_works.role: Canonical framework for partial identification, ignorance regions, and informative bounds without strong point-identifying assumptions.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper adopts Manski’s partial identification perspective to formalize counterfactual ignorance intervals and to emphasize informative bounds over untenable point-ID assumptions.

prior_works.title: Sensitivity Analysis for Selection Bias and Unmeasured Confounding in Missing Data and Causal Inference Models
prior_works.authors: James M. Robins, Andrea Rotnitzky, Daniel O. Scharfstein
prior_works.role: Established the sensitivity-analysis paradigm: specifying structured deviations from ideal assumptions to quantify identification robustness.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposed Curvature Sensitivity Model is a structural analogue of classical sensitivity models, placing interpretable constraints on SCM functions to render counterfactual bounds informative.

prior_works.title: Nonlinear Causal Discovery with Additive Noise Models
prior_works.authors: Patrik O. Hoyer, Dominik Janzing, Joris M. Mooij, Jonas Peters, Bernhard Schölkopf
prior_works.role: Represents point-identifying approaches for continuous SCMs via strong functional-form assumptions (e.g., additive noise, invertibility/monotonicity).
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper explicitly relaxes ANM-style assumptions that enable point counterfactuals, replacing them with weaker, geometrically motivated curvature constraints that yield partial identification.

prior_works.title: What Counterfactuals Can Be Tested?
prior_works.role: Characterized testability/identifiability limits of counterfactual statements in causal models.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By highlighting fundamental non-testability of many counterfactuals, this work motivates the turn to partial identification and sensitivity modeling pursued via curvature constraints.

prior_works.title: Confidence Intervals for Partially Identified Parameters
prior_works.authors: Guido W. Imbens, Charles F. Manski
prior_works.role: Formalized inference when parameters are set-identified, focusing on informative bounds and their statistical interpretation.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s emphasis on informative ignorance intervals for counterfactuals aligns with Imbens–Manski’s framework for reasoning about set-identified quantities.

synthesis_narrative:
The core contribution of Melnychuk, Frauen, and Feuerriegel is to transition counterfactual inference for continuous outcomes from fragile point identification to principled partial identification, delivering informative ignorance intervals under a novel Curvature Sensitivity Model. This builds directly on Pearl’s SCM semantics and the abduction–action–prediction procedure, which define counterfactuals but typically presume strong structure for point identification. Earlier, Balke and Pearl demonstrated that counterfactuals often admit only bounds—frequently vacuous—especially in discrete settings, seeding the idea that identification must be qualified by assumptions. Manski’s partial identification program then provided the general blueprint for working with ignorance regions and informative bounds instead of insisting on point ID.
At the same time, much of the continuous-outcome counterfactual literature has relied on strong functional-form assumptions such as additive noise and invertibility (e.g., ANMs), enabling point counterfactuals but at the cost of realism. Shpitser and Pearl’s results on the non-testability of many counterfactuals underscore the need for transparent, defensible assumptions rather than hidden parametrics. Robins–Rotnitzky–Scharfstein established sensitivity analysis as a rigorous way to encode and vary such assumptions; the present work adapts this paradigm to SCM structure by bounding the curvature of level sets, a geometric constraint that is weaker than ANM-style assumptions yet powerful enough to tighten counterfactual bounds. Finally, the orientation toward informative intervals echoes Imbens–Manski’s set-identification framework, situating the proposed curvature-based bounds within a coherent inferential approach to partially identified counterfactuals.
